page.title: 03EARLY HISTORY
page.content: {Yateley was mentioned in the original Domesday Book but evidence of settlement in this area goes back to the Stone Age. Arrowheads and stone axes and Bronze Age burial urns have been unearthed.The Saxons arrived in AD 700. Yateley, as part of Crondall Hundred, originally appears as a bequest to the old Monastery, Winchester. The early cottages of Yateley were around The Green on which cottagers grazed their livestock. Each family farmed their strip of land. By the 13th Century Yateley was a properous, vigorous community, although in Medieval times the greater greater part of this area was open heathland. Yateley Hall (a pre-Elizabethan Manor House) was once surrounded by a moat and has a priest hole and the wisteria is probably the oldest in the country.
